text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Bulgarian customs officers said they had seized 30 kg of heroin hidden in a Volvo car with two Serbs due from Turkey to Bulgaria at the Bulgarian-Turkish border checkpoint of Kapitan Andreevo.

-- Bulgaria is expected to finalise today the sale of 60 percent of its soda ash producer Sodi Devnya to the Belgian Solvay SA chemical producer for $160 million, prime minister Stefan Sofianski said.

-- Bulgaria's biggest state-owned Bulbank is expected to report a 12.4 billion lev net profit for 1996 at a shareholders' meeting on Thursday, private Balkan new agency said. Around 10 billion levs of the net were expected to be used for a capital rise to 15.124 billion levs.

-- The state-owned United Bulgarian Bank said it would act as a transfer agent for the Central Depositary in over-the-counter trade in shares acquired under the country's voucher privatisation programme.
-- Bulgaria's prime minister Stefan Sofianski is expected to seal today a bilateral accord with Russia on the supply and transit of Russian natural gas.
-- Bulgaria's caretaker cabinet said it would offer for sale up to 75 percent of the country's biggest oil refinery Neftochim.
-- Bulgaria hopes to receive a loan worth some $25-35 million from Russia to complete the construction of the Sofia underground railway, Prime minister Stefan Sofianski said.

-- Bulgaria's Interior ministry said it had launched a second round of its Mosquito operation against tax evasion with checks of 170 real estate deals. More than 14,000 luxury cars were checked under the first round of the operation at the end of March.

-- The Bulgarian Stock Exchange (BSE) now expects to be licenced by the country's Securities and Stock Exchanges Commision after the minimum required capital of 100 million levs was fully paid in, BSE board chairman Viktor Papazov said.

-- A new 100,000-lev note, the largest denomination planned so far, was expected to be put in circulation in September at the earliest to ease big payments in an inflationary environment, the government's press centre said.
